steps.title: Look at the color.
steps.content: Look at the color. Carpenter ants are usually brown or black. [1] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019. Some are a combination of black and orange. While you need more than color to figure out if you have carpenter ants, noting color is a good place to start. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Note size.
steps.content: Note size. As you observe ants, try estimate their size. Carpenter ants are not very big. Normally, you will see worker ants around your home. They are generally 3/8 to 1/2 an inch. [3] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019. [4] X Research source However, in some areas carpenter ants tend to be smaller. In Minnesota, for example, some carpenter ants are only 3/16 of an inch. When noting size, look to other characteristic as well.

steps.title: Watch for a round thorax.
steps.content: Watch for a round thorax. The thorax refers to the segment of an ant just below its head. Carpenter ants have a rounded thorax. The upper surface should be evenly rounded throughout. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Look at the antenna and waist.
steps.content: Look at the antenna and waist. The midsection of a carpenter ant should be pinched and slim in appearance. Their antennae will be bent slightly. [6] X Trustworthy Source University of Georgia Cooperative Extension Division of the University of Georgia focused on research and community education Go to source Noting the antennae and waist helps distinguish carpenter ants from termites. Termites have straight antenna and a broad waist. Compared to some other ants, carpenter ants have 1 node on its waist.

steps.title: Look for piles of wood shavings.
steps.content: Look for piles of wood shavings. [7] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019. Carpenter ants do not eat wood, but they do burrow in it. They will burrow into wood furniture in your home, such as desks or cabinets. If you have a carpenter ant infestation, you may find piles of wood shavings just below wooden objects like desks. [8] X Trustworthy Source University of Georgia Cooperative Extension Division of the University of Georgia focused on research and community education Go to source

steps.title: Listen for ants in the walls.
steps.content: Listen for ants in the walls. Gently tap against the walls in your home while pressing your ear against the wall. Tapping often disturbs an ant nest. If you have an infestation, you may hear a light rustling sound. [9] X Research source While carpenter ants can nest anywhere in your home, they tend to prefer areas near window frames or water sources. It's not uncommon to find carpenter ants in a kitchen or bathroom, for example. Try tapping in these places to find nests.

steps.title: Check for workers at night or early morning.
steps.content: Check for workers at night or early morning. If you suspect you have an infestation, look for workers. Carpenter ants tend to come out after dark, so search for them near where you heard rustling in the early morning or late at night. Use a flashlight to scan for carpenter ants in these places. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Try baited traps.
steps.content: Try baited traps. A mild carpenter ant infestation can be treated at home with baited traps. You can buy such traps at a hardware store. You can set up traps in areas where you have seen carpenter ants traveling. [11] X Research source This usually works best if you have carpenter ants somewhere outside, like your porch. This will prevent the ants from moving indoors. Make sure to check the labels of any traps you use. You may need to keep them out of reach of children and animals.

steps.title: Use commercial bug sprays.
steps.content: Use commercial bug sprays. Sprays can be used to keep an infestation from moving in doors. Purchase bug sprays specifically designed to repel or kill carpenter ants at a local hardware store. Sprays are usually applies in a perimeter around your home. [12] X Research source Make sure to read the label for safe use. Most sprays should be kept out of reach of children and animals.

steps.title: Call in a professional.
steps.content: Call in a professional. [13] X Expert Source Scott McCombe Pest Control Specialist Expert Interview. 19 November 2019. If you have an infestation that does not go away using traps and sprays, call in a professional. Professional exterminators can help locate ant nests and strategically knock out an infestation. [14] X Research source While most exterminators use chemicals and pesticides, if you're uncomfortable with sprays you can discuss natural options with an exterminator. For more tips on dealing with a carpenter ant infestation, check out the discussion on wikiHow's "How do I get rid of carpenter ants in my house?" forum .
